list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Which is characteristic of both prokaryotes and viruses?


- I.Contain genetic codeII.Rely on host cell for metabolismIII.Surrounded by cell wall




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because both prokaryotes and viruses contain a genetic code. Only viruses rely on a host cell for metabolism, and only prokaryotes have a cell wall (Choice B, Choice C, and Choice D).

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Viruses, compared to living organisms, are very small. Which other characteristic listed below distinguishes viruses from unicellular living organisms?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Contain genetic material
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Contain cytoplasm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Lack enzymes
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetic material is surrounded by a capsid
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because The structure of all viruses includes the presence of a capsid, which surrounds the genetic material (Choice D). Both viruses and living organisms contain genetic material (Choice A). Unicellular living organisms contain cytoplasm (Choice B).  Some viruses lack enzymes, but not all viruses lack enzymes (Choice C).

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Bacteriophages and coronaviruses are both viruses that affect living organisms. Which structures are present in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses?


- I.cytoplasmII.capsidIII.genetic material




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because bacteriophages and coronavirus have a capsid and genetic material, and do not have cytoplasm (Choice A, Choice B, and Choice D).

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which of the rows below shows the correct characteristics of viruses, prokaryotes and eukaryotes?

VirusProkaryoteEukaryoteA.$\hspace{1em}$Genome is DNA or RNAGenome is DNA onlyGenome is DNA onlyB.$\hspace{1em}$Rely on host cell for nutritionRely on host cell for nutritionDoes not rely on host cell for nutritionC.$\hspace{1em}$Synthesises ATP for energy supplySynthesises ATP for energy supplySynthesises ATP for energy supplyD.$\hspace{1em}$Capsid presentCapsid presentCapsid present
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because viruses contain DNA or RNA as their genome. Viruses rely on host cells for nutrition, but prokaryotes and eukaryotes do not (Choice B). Prokaryotes and eukaryotes synthesise ATP, but viruses do not (Choice C). Capsids are present in viruses but not in prokaryotes or eukaryotes (Choice D).

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Viruses have specific components that allow them to infect host cells and replicate. However, some components are not found in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses. Which of the following is not present in BOTH types of viruses?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetic information surrounded by a capsid
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ RNA genome
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Enzymes for replication
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Structures for attachment to a host cell
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because lambda bacteriophages and coronavirus do not have enzymes for replication. The lambda bacteriophage relies entirely on the host cell's machinery for replication and
coronaviruses encode their replication enzyme but do not carry it in the virion.
Choice A is incorrect because both have a capsid containing genetic information.
Choice B is incorrect because although the lambda bacteriophage has a DNA genome, not an RNA genome, coronaviruses do have an RNA genome.
Choice D is incorrect because both of these types of viruses have structures for attachment to the host cells.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Some bacteriophages infect host bacteria using the lytic cycle or the lysogenic cycle.
Which process is characteristic of the lysogenic cycle but not the lytic cycle?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Phage DNA is injected into the host cell.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The phage inserts DNA into host DNA, forming a prophage.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Host bacterium is killed by cell lysis.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Phage proteins bind to receptors on the host bacterium cell.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because phage DNA is inserted into the host cell DNA in the lysogenic cycle, but not the lytic cycle. During the lysogenic cycle and lytic cycle, phage proteins bind to specific receptors on the surface of the host bacterium (Choice D). Phage DNA is then inserted into the host bacterium (Choice A) in both the lysogenic cycle and lytic cycle.  Host bacterial cells are killed by lysis in the lytic cycle (Choice C).

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Which is not a factor in the rapid evolution of the human immunodeficiency virus?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetic recombination
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ High mutation rate
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Slow replication rate
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetic diversity of host population
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because a slow replication rate is not a factor in the rapid evolution of HIV. Genetic recombination occurs when many strains of the virus infect the same host, and a new combination of genetic material is observed, which leads to changes in the virus (evolution) over time (Choice A).   Mutations occur rapidly in HIV because it is a single-stranded RNA virus and lacks a mechanism to proofread the genome. The introduction of this variation leads to evolution (Choice B). The genome of humans and the HIV host population, has high genetic diversity. Such diversity in the genome may provide a selective advantage for some HIV strains (Choice D).

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Which gives the best summary of the action of reverse transcriptase?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ viral DNA $\rarr$ viral RNA
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ viral DNA
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ host cell RNA
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ viral RNA $\rarr$ host cell DNA
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because reverse transcriptase is an enzyme used by retroviruses (e.g. HIV) to convert their RNA genome into a DNA copy. This DNA copy is then integrated into the host cell’s genome, allowing the virus to hijack the host's transcription and translation machinery to produce viral proteins and replicate itself.
Choice A is incorrect because a DNA-containing virus would simply use the host cell’s replication mechanisms to replicate its DNA; there would be no need for reverse transcription.
Choice C is incorrect because reverse transcription involves the conversion of RNA into DNA.
Choice D is incorrect because, whilst the viral DNA copy does get incorporated into the host cell’s genome, this cannot be regarded as host cell DNA as it remains distinct from the host's original DNA. It is not accurate to refer to this DNA as "host cell DNA" since it originates from the virus.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The origin of viruses is an area of active research and exploration. Which statement is not evidence that viruses have origins in other organisms?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Similarities between genome sequence in viral and cellular genes.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Coevolution of viruses and host.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Retroviral enzymes such as reverse transcriptase convert RNA to DNA.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Rate of mutation is rapid in viruses.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the rapid mutation rate is not evidence of viral origins, but rather a characteristic of some viruses.   Similarities between genome sequences in viral and cellular genes (Choice A), the coevolution of viruses and hosts (Choice B), and retroviral enzymes converting RNA to DNA (Choice C),  are all evidence of viral origins from other organisms.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: - Outline the varied forms of genetic material found in viruses. [4] - Discuss the evidence supporting that the diversity of viruses exists as a result of convergent evolution. [4] - Compare the structure of the coronavirus with the human immunodeficiency virus, HIV. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ single-stranded RNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ single-stranded DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ double-stranded RNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ double-stranded DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleic acid OR DNA OR RNA [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: There are many different types of viruses. The types of genetic information found in different types of viruses include single-stranded RNA ($\checkmark$), double-stranded RNA ($\checkmark$), single-stranded DNA ($\checkmark$), and double-stranded DNA ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ convergent evolution refers to the appearance of similar traits in unrelated organisms as a response to similar selection pressures [1] $\ce{ -> }$ viruses exhibit a wide range of forms OR structures OR mechanisms to adapt to different hosts OR environments [1] $\ce{ -> }$ presence of a capsid surrounding genetic material OR nucleocapsid is a shared feature that evolved independently in different viral lineages [1] $\ce{ -> }$ presence of specific protein receptors or spikes have evolved independently to facilitate host cell attachment OR suitable example such as similar spike proteins in coronaviruses and influenza viruses [1] $\ce{ -> }$ independent evolution of similar replication enzymes OR reverse transcriptase [1] $\ce{ -> }$ viruses utilise either DNA OR RNA as their genetic material, demonstrating molecular convergence in adapting to different replication strategies [1] $\ce{ -> }$ convergent traits enhance viral fitness by aiding in host cell attachment OR immune evasion OR efficient replication [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Convergent evolution occurs when unrelated organisms evolve similar traits due to similar selection pressures ($\checkmark$). In viruses, an example is the independent evolution of protein spikes in coronaviruses and influenza viruses to aid in host cell attachment ($\checkmark$). Similarly, unrelated viruses have independently evolved reverse transcriptase for efficient replication ($\checkmark$). Additionally, viruses use either DNA or RNA as genetic material, showing molecular convergence in adapting to various replication needs ($\checkmark$). - Seven of the following (there must be at least one similarity and one difference): Similarities $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are spherical in shape [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain (viral) envelope, OR both are enveloped with a lipid bilayer [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain RNA as the genetic material [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain a capsid [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain spikes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH spikes are made of glycoprotein [1] Differences $\ce{ -> }$ HIV contains reverse transcriptase, WHILE coronaviruses do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ HIV contains two (single) strands of RNA, WHILE the coronavirus contains one single strand of RNA OR HIV genome is shorter or about 10,000 nucleotides, WHILE coronavirus is longer (about 30,000 nucleotides) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ HIV has an enveloped capsid, WHILE coronavirus contains a helical (nucleo)capsid [1] $\ce{ -> }$ HIV genome is within enveloped capsid, WHILE coronavirus genome is a nucleocapsid/not in envelope [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: In comparing the coronavirus and the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), there are several similarities and differences. Both the coronavirus and HIV are spherical in shape ($\checkmark$), the genetic information is enclosed by a capsid ($\checkmark$), and both types of viruses contain RNA as the genetic material ($\checkmark$). However, HIV is a retrovirus and contains the enzyme reverse transcriptase, while the coronavirus does not contain reverse transcriptase ($\checkmark$). Both viruses contain spikes ($\checkmark$) for attachment to cells, and both HIV spikes and coronavirus spikes are made of glycoprotein ($\checkmark$). HIV contains two single strands of RNA; however, the coronavirus contains one single strand of RNA ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Which is not characteristic of HIV?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The viral RNA encodes for reverse transcriptase
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Spike glycoproteins allow for entry into CD4 cells
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Two single strands of RNA are encased in a capsid
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Integrase proteins are required for entry into a host cell
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because integrase proteins are not required to enter the host cell; integrase proteins are needed to integrate viral genetic information into host DNA. All other answer options (Choice A, Choice B, and Choice C) are characteristics of HIV.
